respStmt.resp: Transcribed from images of original letters
respStmt.name: Sarah Tew
Giuliano Sidro
Millie You
Maddie Qualls

publicationStmt.distributor: The Center for the Tebtunis Papyri, The University of California, Berkeley
publicationStmt.authority: The Board of Trinity College Dublin, The University of Dublin

availability.p: Available for academic research purposes only.

objectDesc.p: Handwritten letter of 3 pages on one folded sheet with writing on front and back. There is no writing on the back page of the folded sheet.
Catalog number '83' written in pencil. The "83" possibly overwrites a former erased catolog number.

recordHist.p: Images taken from Trinity College, Dublin: Page 1Pages 2-3Pages 4-5Page6

projectDesc.p: This document was created as part of the History of Papyrology project [https://histpap.info/] by Sarah Tew, Giuliano Sidro, Maddie Qualls, and Millie You. The project is in affiliation the Center for Tebtunis Papyri at the University of California, Berkeley.

editorialDecl.p: Text has been transcribed diplomatically without corrections, normalization, or standardization.

punctuation.p: All punction marks have been retained nd represented using the appropriate Unicode code character except for apostrophes and ampersands which have been escaped using ' and &, respectively.

segmentation.p: The text has been segmented into lines according to line breaks in the original text automatically by Transkribus and line groupings based on groups identified automatically or manually declared by Sarah Tew in Transkribus. Page breaks have been manually edited by Sarah Tew, Giuliano Sidro, Maddie Qualls, and Millie You after export from Transkribus.

handNotes.handNote: Written in black ink by B.P. Grenfell.

revisionDesc.change: Manually added TEI header to Transkribus tei.xml exported file.

body.ab:
My dear Smyly,
I hope 'Cleg Kelly' has reached
you all right. It lasted me as far as
Rugby on a very pleasant journey, the sea
bring like a lake.
The Fund agreed to our proposals without
discussion. They had been wrangling for
half an hour about Naville and Sir John
Evans, not being a subscriber to the G.R.B,
was too bored to discuss it. So I have
written to the Americans, though whether I
shall get an answer is very doubtful. But

we shall proceed on the hypothesis that
next year's vol. is to be a crocodile one,
and shall expect you here in October.
Gradenwitz now proposes to come here at
the beginning. of August. I hope he will
be presentable!
I had a very pleasant inside of a week
in town, though not such as to efface
the memory of my Dublin visit. Petrie's
show is well worth visiting, if only for
the Aegean pots warranted (by P.)
comtemporary with the 1st dynasty. I also
went to the Wallace Collection. The
French pictures are I suppose valuable

historically, but interested me less
than the Dutch and English ones, which
are superb. By the way is your
(engaged) sister aware of the likeness
between herself and the famous 'Nelly
O'Brien'. If not, let her go and study it.
Remember me to Mahaffy when you see
him and thank him for forwarding the
letters. He is, I understand, to pay
Lord Amherst a visit this week; I am
sorry I have not time to go down there too.

Thanking you even more for all your
hospitality,
Yours ever
Bernard P. Grenfell.
